title-group.article-title: Retroperitoneal Trapdoor Endarterectomy for Paravisceral “Coral-reef” Aortic Plaque

contrib-group.aff: 1Division of Vascular Surgery, Ronald Reagan Medical Center, UCLA School of Medicine, Los Angeles, CA, USA

author-notes.corresp: Brian G. DeRubertis, Gonda Vascular Center, UCLA Division of Vascular Surgery, 200 Medical Plaza, Suite 510-6, Los Angeles, CA 90095, USA Email: bderubertis@mednet.ucla.edu

abstract.p: A 67-year-old woman presented to the emergency room with progressive claudication, chest pain, and flash-pulmonary edema. Her past medical history was significant for poorly controlled hypertension requiring multiple antihypertensive medications, renal insufficiency, and tobacco abuse. Diagnostic evaluation revealed an extensive exophytic plaque localized to the paravisceral aorta resulting in high-grade stenoses of the proximal aorta as well as the celiac, superior mesenteric, and left renal arteries. She underwent surgical revascularization through a retroperitoneal aortic exposure and trapdoor aortic endarterectomy, the technical conduct of which is described in this manuscript. The patient recovered uneventfully and experienced resolution of her claudication and pulmonary symptoms, improved blood pressure control, and normalization of her creatinine. Review of the medical literature pertaining to management of proximal occlusive disease of the abdominal aorta is discussed.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Severe focal atherosclerotic occlusive disease of the aorta is a rare entity that has been described in both the thoracic and proximal abdominal aorta.1–18 The term “coral-reef plaque” was first used by Stoney and colleagues in 1984 to describe heavily calcified atherosclerotic plaque in the proximal abdominal aorta leading to occlusions or stenoses of the mesenteric and renal arteries and the abdominal aorta. 2 While the intraluminal appearance of the plaque is exophytic and extensive in nature, the disease process is often largely confined to a short segment of the aorta and can, therefore, be approached surgically through focal endarterectomy of the involved aorta and its branches.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A 67-year-old woman presented to the emergency room with progressive claudication, chest pain, and flash pulmonary edema. Two years prior, the patient endorsed an exercise tolerance of 3 to 4 flights of stairs without shortness of breath and a daily ambulation routine of 4 miles per day. Over the preceding 12 months, she developed increasingly severe claudication to the extent that she was now limited after less than 30 ft. Additionally, she had developed paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea and had been treated for several episodes of flash-pulmonary edema. Her cardiovascular risk factors included a 50 pack-year tobacco abuse history, renal insufficiency (with a current creatinine of 1.8 mg/dL), and refractory hypertension (requiring 4 medications). On physical examination, she was found to have a blood pressure of 210/140 mm Hg, bilateral lung rales, diminished femoral pulses, and absent pedal pulses. Chest x-ray revealed cardiomegaly and pulmonary vascular congestion consistent with pulmonary edema. Cardiac evaluation revealed normal cardiac enzymes, absence of myocardial ischemia on adenosine myoview examination, and normal ejection fraction on echocardiogram. Axial imaging studies included magnetic resonance angiography (Figure 1) revealing an extensive paravisceral atherosclerotic aortic plaque. This lesion consisted of an irregular heavily calcified process confined to the lumen of the aorta in the region of the mesenteric and renal arteries. It resulted in a near-occlusive stenosis of the abdominal aorta as well as high-grade stenoses of celiac, superior mesenteric artery (SMA), and left renal arteries. Endovascular and open surgical treatment options were discussed, and the patient decided to proceed with aortic endarterectomy.

caption.p: Magnetic resonance angiogram revealing focal paravisceral aortic plaque with exophytic intraluminal surface (red arrow). Note high-grade stenoses of celiac, superior mesenteric artery (SMA), and renal arteries (yellow arrows).

sec.title: Operative Management
sec.p: The patient underwent trapdoor aortic endarterectomy through a retroperitoneal approach. For this procedure, general anesthesia is administered and after placing appropriate intravenous access lines, hemodynamic monitoring devices, and a urinary catheter, the patient is placed on a bean bag in the left lateral decubitus position with the bed flexed 30° between the costal margin and the anterior-superior iliac spine. An oblique incision centered on the 10th interspace is made from the costal margin to the lateral edge of the rectus sheath anteriorly. The underlying muscle and fascial layers are divided until reaching the peritoneum which is then gently swept anteriorly to develop the retroperitoneal space. Dissection continues posteriorly and the left kidney is retracted anteriorly to approach the posterolateral surface of the aorta. Once a sufficient portion of the supraceliac aorta has been exposed for clamping, the celiac, SMA, and left renal arteries are dissected out to a soft part of each vessel and ensnared with vessel loops. Left retroperitoneal exposure will generally allow sufficient dissection of the right renal artery as well (Figure 2), provided the plaque within this vessel is limited to the orifice as is generally the case. If circumferential dissection of this vessel is not possible, it can be controlled with a transluminal occlusion balloon after opening the aorta. At this point, the patient is systemically anticoagulated with 100 U/kg of intravenous heparin and the distal and proximal aortic cross-clamps are applied. The posterior wall of the aorta can now be dissected to expose and clip and visible lumbar arteries in this region (Figure 3A). A trapdoor arteriotomy is made, extending from the soft portion of the supraceliac aorta down to the infrarenal aorta, coursing posterior and lateral to the mesenteric and left renal arteries (Figure 3B). Next, a Penfield elevator is used to begin a dissection plane in the deep medial layer of the aortic wall, removing the plaque en-bloc and leaving behind the circular muscle fibers of the aortic medial layer (Figure 3C). Careful dissection allows en-bloc removal of the plaque with eversion endarterectomy performed at each of the renal and mesenteric orifices. The focal nature of the atherosclerotic process generally allows the removal of the plaques with a feathered end point, but if necessary, additional tacking sutures can be placed. Once the endarterectomy is completed, the arteriotomy is closed with running continuous 3-0 prolene suture. After retrograde back-bleeding through the renal and mesenteric vessels is performed and the proximal and distal aorta is flushed out, the arteriotomy closure is completed and flow is reestablished. Doppler flow signals are then assessed in all branch vessels and then the retroperitoneal incision is closed.

caption.p: Dissection of the mesenteric and renal vessels, including the right renal artery. The proximal portion of the right renal can usually be dissected through this approach, especially if its origin is slightly anterior.

A, Clipping of a lumbar artery to control back-bleeding during the endarterectomy. B, Course of the trapdoor arteriotomy (yellow arrows). C, Endarterectomy of the aortic plaque. Note the circular muscle fibers of the deep medial layer which are left with the aortic wall. These fibers indicate that the correct plane has been established and prevent overthinning of the aortic wall.

sec.p: The patient had an uneventful recovery and was discharged home on the sixth postoperative day. Patency and freedom from stenosis was demonstrated in all mesenteric and renal vessels on follow-up abdominal duplex ultrasound (Figure 4A-C) and computed tomography angiogram (Figure 4D-F). At a follow-up of 19 months, she is now free from claudication, abdominal symptoms, or pulmonary edema. She is normotensive on 2 medications and with a normal creatinine level.

caption.p: Abdominal duplex at follow-up demonstrates widely patent celiac (A), superior mesenteric (B), and right renal (C) arteries. These findings were confirmed on a computed tomography (CT) angiogram performed for other indications (D-F).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The term “coral-reef” aortic plaque was first coined by Stoney and colleagues in 1984 and was used to describe extensive calcified intraluminal atherosclerotic plaque in the pararenal aorta. 2 This condition is a rare pathologic entity that results in almost complete obliteration of the suprarenal abdominal aorta, leading to symptoms of hypertension and bilateral lower extremity claudication almost invariably. Additional symptoms can include renal insufficiency, mesenteric ischemia, congestive heart failure, blue-toe syndrome, and occasionally, limb threat due to acute aortic thrombosis.

Slightly more than 50 cases of coral-reef atherosclerotic plaque of the upper abdominal aorta have been reported in the medical literature (Table 1). Review of these cases reveals that this entity is slightly more common in women, is associated with heavy use of tobacco in most cases, and commonly exists in the absence of significant atherosclerotic disease of the remainder of the peripheral circulation. 1–18

caption.p: Summary of Reported Cases of Paravisceral Coral-reef Aortic Plaque.

sec.p: While endovascular intervention may be feasible in mild cases, the calcific and exophytic nature of these lesions typically dictates an open surgical approach. Small case report series suggest that thoracic endograft placement or laparoscopic excision of these lesions may be feasible, although generally they are treated with either aortic replacement, surgical bypass, or in most cases, aortic endarterectomy. 1,18 As demonstrated in this report, aortic endarterectomy for extensive intraluminal can be performed through a retroperitoneal incision with short cross-clamp times and excellent clinical results. Clinical improvement was rapid, and the patient had resolution of her hypertension, azotemia, and claudication symptoms by the first postoperative visit. Review of the other cases in the literature (Table 1) suggests that open surgical repair is safe, with an overall perioperative mortality rate of 12%, although mortality with endarterectomy is significantly lower. These results highlight the continued importance of the technique detailed above and illustrate the value of open surgical revascularization even in the face of rapidly evolving endovascular technologies.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In summary, coral-reef plaque of the upper abdominal aorta is an uncommon clinical entity that can present with compromise to the renal and visceral circulations, leading to hypertension, claudication, renal insufficiency, congestive heart failure, and mesenteric ischemia. The focal nature of the disease lends it to treatment with aortic endarterectomy, which can result in long-term symptom improvement.
